ordination activities with local, state, and federal emergency planning and response organizations are done at least annually. If the facility is modified, the Emergency Response Plan (ICP) is updated as needed to include any new refinery units and changes to operations and facility personnel are informed of the change(s). 

MANAGEMENT SYSTEMS
The Refinery Manager is ultimately responsible for implementation of the risk management measures set forth in this document. The PSM Lead is responsible for upkeep of the Risk Management Plan and Hazard Assessment, and all supporting documentation. The individual departments assigned above implement each element of the Prevention Program.

ENHANCEMENTS TO SAFETY
Phillips 66 is committed to the continuous improvement of safety at the Ferndale Refinery. The use of prevention programs required by RMP (including PHAs, incident investigations, audits, and testing and inspection results), as well as other safety and risk reduction initiatives, ensure that the necessary modifications are implemented to maintain and enhance safety at the facility.
 
The following are examples of the types of safety-enhancing modifications made to the facility during the period from 2018 to 2023:
1. Additional improvements have been made to pumps and compressors to prevent seal failures, such as pump replacements, seal modifications, safety interlocks, etc.
2. Additional Safety Instrumented Systems interlocks, controls or parameters have been installed in Unit 1 Crude, Unit 4 FCC, Unit 5 FCC Gas Plant, Unit 9 Offplot, Unit 16 Alky Gas Plant, Unit 17 HF Alky, Unit 18 Reformer, and Unit 38 Szorb.
3. Firewater piping, valving, and hydrant improvements have been made.
5. New Plant Response Center and North Field Operating Center have been constructed. 

The following list includes some of the future projects that will be implemented to enhance safety:
1. Existing Safety Instrumented Systems in the process units will be upgraded.
2. Additional improvements

meter monitors allow for rapid detection and response in the event of a leak of hydrofluoric acid from the Alkylation Unit

EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM
The refinery provides resources for planning in case of emergencies at the facility. The facility is a responsible member of the community by protecting the refinery and neighbors from damaging effects of emergency situations. The facility design, maintenance, operating procedures, and training provide for risk minimization should an accident occur. In spite of all these things, emergencies can arise, sometimes through forces beyond our control. The facility emergency response plan known as the Integrated Contingency Plan (ICP), along with training and drills, is designed to prepare the facility to recognize emergency situations of various types and react promptly and correctly to minimize any ill effects. Local, state, and federal safety rules dictate that the facility study and understand the principles and specifics covered in this preplanning effort and fully understand all roles in the plan. Local, state, and federal emergency planning and response organizations are provided a copy of the ICP.

The purpose of this emergency plan (ICP) is to provide a cohesive, written procedure for coordinating an effective response by all refinery personnel so that danger to employees, contractors, the general public, and the environment may be lessened in the unlikely event of an emergency. The emergency response procedure covers the entire facility, including refinery units that don’t handle or produce regulated substances. It includes but is not limited to: first-in response, evacuation, emergency shutdown, decontamination and medical response to chemical exposure, agency notification, public notification if potential for impact, personnel accounting, and clean-up.

Training for emergency response is handled through the HSE Department, and is conducted frequently with classroom, tabletop, and field exercises. Additionally, co

ed to the Program level 3 refining processes at the Facility. Collectively, these prevention program activities help prevent potential accident scenarios that could be caused by equipment failures and/or human errors.

Some of the administrative programs to prevent, detect, or mitigate an incident at the facility are presented above. Specific safety equipment and procedures, known as safeguards, are in place at the facility. These safeguards are listed as part of the process hazard analyses, process safety information, and operating procedures. Some examples of general safeguards are presented below:

Release Detection
	Hydrogen sulfide, hydrogen fluoride, and hydrocarbon detectors with alarms
	Facility alarm system to notify personnel in case of emergency
	Ambient SO2 Monitoring Station

Release Containment/Control
	Pressure Safety Valves (PSVs) to protect all pressure vessels
	Operating materials recovery system with process flare to incinerate excess materials from the process
	Manual and automatic valves to permit isolation of the process
	Automated shutdown systems for specific process parameters
	Excess flow valves that prevent product loss if a loading line should fail 
	Fail-Safe valves to isolate equipment in case of unplanned events such as power failures and earthquakes
	Containment around all tanks and process areas to contain liquid materials
	Backup power supply for critical process equipment

Release Mitigation
	Fire suppression and extinguishing systems
	Deluge system for specific equipment
	Trained emergency response personnel
	Personal protective equipment (e.g., protective clothing, self-contained breathing apparatus)
	Blast-resistant buildings to help protect control systems and personnel
	Backup fire protection equipment

Other specific safeguards include:
	Acid Inventory Management System (AIMS) for the hydrofluoric acid in the Alkylation Unit to minimize the potential release in the case of a leak or equipment damage
	Peri

ion programs.

PP11. Incident Investigation
The incident investigation program expands beyond what is required for the EPA RMP regulation. In addition to incidents that have the potential to result in a catastrophic release of a regulated substance, it also covers all other incidents and near misses that occur at the refinery. Examples include, but are not limited to: process safety incidents, occupational injuries and illness, unit upsets, production loss, property damage or loss, and environmental incidents such as spills or releases. Incident investigation is the responsibility of the PSM Lead.

The intent is to ensure that investigations are conducted in a timely, organized, and objective manner. The purpose of an investigation is not to fix blame, but rather to determine the facts surrounding the incident, present the findings and conclusions, and make recommendations for corrective actions that will prevent a similar occurrence in the future. An incident investigation team will investigate all incidents as defined in Section 68.81 of the Chemical Accident Prevention Provisions.

All process safety near misses and incidents are reviewed during the 5-year revalidation of the unit PHA studies, to provide the PHA team with insight into hazards that may occur.

PP12.	Compliance Audits
To help ensure that the accident prevention program is functioning properly, the Ferndale Refinery periodically conducts an audit to determine whether the procedures and practices required by the accident prevention program are being implemented.

This facility verifies RMP compliance every three years with an audit. The refinery will retain the two most recent compliance audit reports for inspection. The PSM Lead is responsible for the compliance audit portion of the prevention program.

 
CHEMICAL SPECIFIC PREVENTION STEPS
The processes at the refinery have hazards that must be managed to ensure continued safe operation. The accident prevention program summarized previously is appli

re that equipment used to process, store or handle hazardous chemicals is designed, constructed, installed, inspected, and maintained per good engineering practices. This will minimize the risk of releases of such chemicals. The facility has programs for:
	Safety systems
	Control and instrumentation systems
	Pumps and compressors
	Furnaces
	Relief devices
	Piping systems
	Valves
	Tanks and storage vessels
	Pressure vessels, heat exchangers, and boilers

The ANSI/ISA S84.01 Safety Instrumented Systems guidance has been adopted by the facility and is used to ensure reliability for all new installations of safety instrumented systems and equipment.

The facility uses input from multiple sources, including the PHA studies, to determine which equipment is integral to the safety of the facility, and provides critical maintenance and reliability checks accordingly.

The Maintenance Manager has overall responsibility for the Mechanical Integrity program. 

PP9.	Hot Work 
The refinery provides a safe and healthy workplace for employees, contractors, visitors, and the community surrounding the facility. Hot work policies and procedures, along with training of affected personnel and contractors, form a system to help ensure that operations and maintenance activities are performed safely. Hot work safe practices are the responsibility of the Health and Safety Team Lead. 

PP10.	Management of Change
The intent of this program is to ensure changes are recognized, formally evaluated, documented, approved by qualified personnel, and communicated to affected employees prior to their implementation. This includes changes to equipment, process chemicals, processing conditions, procedures, facilities, etc., other than replacement in kind.  The management of change process includes a hazard evaluation of applicable changes using the appropriate methodology (Checklist, What-If, HAZOP, etc.). Management of Change is the responsibility of the PSM Lead and encompasses all prevent

stand the nature and causes of problems arising from the process operations. It will also increase employee awareness of the hazards of a particular process, thereby preventing unplanned catastrophic incidents. Operations training is the responsibility of the Learning and Development Site Advisor.

All affected employees are trained on changes to the facility, including the startup of new refinery units, and receive refresher training to ensure that all required skills and knowledge are current. 

PP6. Contractors
It is the refinery philosophy that all injuries are preventable. This applies to all personnel on the Ferndale site whether they are Phillips 66 employees or contract employees. Contract employees are used throughout the refinery, especially in times of construction, turnaround, or startup, and they are required to adhere to the same safety standards as Phillips 66 employees. The contractor safety program is intended to help assure the refinery that its contractors and subcontractors are qualified and have an effective safety process that meets the requirements of the refinery. Contractors are the responsibility of the Health and Safety Team Lead.

PP7. Pre-Startup Safety Reviews (PSSRs)
The purpose of the Pre-Startup Safety Review procedure is to ensure that a new unit or a modification to an existing unit is ready to operate safely. This is a final review to ensure that all important considerations have been taken into account before a change is implemented in the process unit. This includes a check to ensure that all portions of the Management of Change program have been followed, including conducting a PHA, updating Process Safety Information, training personnel, and developing operating and emergency response procedures. It also provides field verification that the equipment is constructed and installed as designed. The PSM Lead is responsible for the PSSR program.

PP8. Mechanical Integrity
The objective of the Mechanical Integrity Program is to assu

rogram.

The Phillips 66 risk matrix is used to qualitatively assign a risk ranking to each hazard scenario based on the potential severity and likelihood, given existing control measures. Any recommendations needed to mitigate a hazardous consequence made in the PHA study receive a priority ranking based on the risk ranking for the associated hazard scenario. All PHA recommendations receive a thorough evaluation in a timely manner. In addition, other risk management tools, such as Layer of Protection Analysis (LOPA) Quantitative Risk Analysis (QRA) and Safety Integrity Level (SIL) evaluation, are also used to ensure there are adequate safeguards in place and safety systems meet reliability requirements.

Changes to the refinery, including new refinery units, are evaluated using a PHA (as applicable) with ample time for recommendation implementation prior to the startup of the unit or change. All PHA studies are retained and may be reviewed by refinery personnel.

PP4. Operating Procedures
The facility develops and implements written operating procedures that provide instructions for safely conducting activities in each processing unit. The tasks and procedures are appropriate, clear, consistent, and communicated with the employees. Operating procedures are the responsibility of the Business Team Leads.

Operating procedures address all applicable modes of operation, including startup, shutdown, normal operation, emergency shutdown, and temporary operations. Knowledgeable employees periodically review operating procedures to ensure that they are current and accurate. Any changes to procedures are communicated to the affected employees.

PP5. Training
The intent of the facility training program is to ensure that the products processed in this facility are handled in a consistent and safe manner. This is accomplished by having well-trained employees. An effective training program will help unit operators, shift supervisors, maintenance personnel, and technicians under

t investigations are available to employees and are reviewed with affected personnel, including contractors. Lessons learned are highlighted in safety moments issued to the site. 

Hot Work Permit: Qualified field operators issue hot work permits. Hourly representatives from the Operations and Maintenance departments participate on the Joint Health and Safety Committee, and review changes and updates to the hot work policy.

Contractors: Contractors working on or adjacent to a covered process must have the hazards associated with those processes communicated to them. Communication between the PSM department and contractors is conducted through monthly contractor safety meetings. 

Compliance Audits: Compliance audits are conducted with participation from hourly and salaried personnel, including contractors. 

PP2. Process Safety Information (PSI)
The refinery provides complete and accurate information concerning all covered processes. This information is essential for having an effective process safety management program and for conducting a thorough process hazards analysis. This includes information regarding process chemicals, process technology, and process equipment. Responsibility for specific PSI documents has been assigned to subject matter experts at the refinery. The Technical Manager has overall responsibility for the PSI program. 

PP3. Process Hazard Analysis (PHA)
The refinery has a comprehensive program to help ensure that hazards associated with the various processes are identified and controlled. Within this program, each refinery processing unit is systematically examined to identify hazards and ensure that adequate controls are in place to manage these hazards. The PHA team identifies and evaluates hazards of the process, as well as accident prevention and mitigation measures. The team also makes suggestions for additional prevention and/or mitigation measures when they believe such measures are necessary. The PSM Lead is responsible for the PHA p

re current and thorough documentation of the equipment and safety systems at the refinery. PSI is available to all employees.

Process Hazard Analysis (PHA): All process hazard analysis studies completed require that an employee knowledgeable in the specific process be a member of the study team. This includes an operations representative and a process engineer with experience in the system being reviewed. The results of all PHAs are made available to all employees and contractors. 

Operating Procedures: Employees knowledgeable in specific processes are asked to develop and review operating procedures to ensure that the procedures are current and thorough. 

Training: The Joint Operations Training Steering Committee and the Maintenance Training Steering Committee are responsible for recommending specific types and forms of training. Composition of the committee requires employee representation from various appropriate groups within the refinery organization.

Management of Change: Employees and contractors participate in the Management of Change (MOC) process by actively participating in design review meetings and pre-startup safety reviews. MOC details are communicated to employees through the MOC log book and training. 

Pre-Startup Safety Reviews: Pre-Startup Safety Reviews (PSSRs) are completed as part of the Management of Change process. The MOC responsible person and an Operations representative from the specific process area being modified participate in the PSSR.

Mechanical Integrity: Aspects of the mechanical integrity provisions of the PSM standard are addressed by the appropriate departments, which includes individuals with relevant technical expertise. Employees participate directly by completing preventative maintenance (PMs), positive material identification, alloy recognition, and adherence to MOC repair requirements. 

Incident Investigation: Employee representatives are asked to participate in formal incident investigations. The results of inciden

es allocated to ensuring the safe design, installation, operation, inspection, and maintenance of our processes and associated equipment. Our approach is to implement reasonable controls to prevent and/or mitigate foreseeable releases of regulated substances. However, if a loss of containment should occur, our emergency response organization will respond to control and contain the release.

The following is a summary of the general accident prevention program in place at the refinery. Because processes at the facility regulated by the EPA RMP regulation are also subject to the OSHA/DOSH PSM standard, the accident prevention and risk management plan is organized to be consistent with the PSM regulation requirements. This summary addresses each of the PSM elements and describes the management system in place to implement the accident prevention program. Each section below contains a brief summary of the prevention program elements and designates the responsible party for each element.

PP1. Employee Participation: 
The intent of this element is to involve employees in the development and implementation of the various PSM element compliance activities. This involvement is intended to be a cooperative, interactive effort that will bring together the best resources at the refinery to achieve a sound loss prevention program. Employee Participation is the responsibility of the PSM Lead.

The Joint Health and Safety Committee (JHSC) is a group that meets monthly to discuss safety concerns and reviews facility policies and procedures. The JHSC is comprised of labor representatives and salaried employees. The JHSC also has many subcommittees that focus on various areas of safety. 

The Ferndale refinery encourages personnel to participate in all aspects of the prevention program. Employees are involved in all the PSM elements, as described below:

Process Safety Information (PSI): Employees knowledgeable in the specific process are asked to assist in the upkeep of PSI to ensu

values have been established, RMP requires that the ERPG-2 value be used as the toxic endpoint. RMP also requires an offsite consequence analysis for potential releases of flammable materials. In modeling flammable materials, the stationary source is required to present distances to endpoints resulting from any of the following:
	Explosion: Overpressure of 1 psig
	Radiant Heat/Fire: Radiant heat of 5 kW/m2 for 40 seconds
	Lower Flammability Limit: a lower flammability limit as provided in NFPA documents or other generally recognized sources

The facility has modeled alternative release scenarios (ARSs) to show release scenarios that may have a more realistic chance of occurrence. The alternative release scenarios allow the facility to present scenarios that assume the use of administrative and actual controls in place at the facility. Even the ARSs are rare events. The details of the process release conditions assumed for the hazard scenarios and assumptions made are provided in the Worst and Alternative Case Release Scenarios sections of the 2023 RMP Update Report. 

FIVE YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY
The RMP rule requires facilities to compile a 5-Year Accident History for all RMP regulated substances in covered processes at the facility. As part of the ongoing PSM Program, the facility documents and tracks all incidents and near misses that occur within the facility. This incident database serves as the basis for the five-year accident history.
RMP requires facilities to report any incident from a covered process involving a regulated substance and resulting in any of the following:
	Onsite deaths, injuries, or significant property damage
	Offsite deaths, injuries, property damage, evacuations, sheltering-in-place, or environmental damage

The Facility has had no RMP reportable incidents in the last 5 years. 

PREVENTION PROGRAM
The Phillips 66 Ferndale Refinery is committed to the safety of its workers and the public. This commitment is demonstrated by the resourc

facility has the utility and support systems required to provide for safe operation of the facility.
The refinery has eleven RMP-covered process units, including the Crude Unit, Fluidized Catalytic Cracking (FCC) Unit, FCC Gas Plant, Offplot, Alky Saturated Gas Plant, Alkylation Unit, Reformer Unit, Butamer Unit, Merox Unit, Szorb Unit, and LSR Hydrotreater. The following regulated substances are onsite above threshold quantities:
1-Butene	
2-Methyl-1-butene	
Ethane	
Methane
1-Pentene	
2-Pentene, E-	
Hydrofluoric acid

The RMP contains two parts required for submittal:
	RMP Executive Summary, Prevention Program Summary, and Management System Summary
	RMP Data Elements

The following changes have been made to the RMP submission documents as part of the revalidation in 2023: 
1.	Revised inventory data based on updated process equipment inventories and lab data compiled in 2023
2.	Revalidated Toxic and Flammable Worst Case and Alternative Case Release Scenarios with current Maximum Intended Inventories (MII) and census data and updated as needed

HAZARD ASSESSMENT RESULTS 
The objectives of this hazard assessment are twofold: (1) satisfy the requirements of the RMP regulation and (2) provide Offsite Consequence Analysis (OCA) information that will help local emergency planning officials improve community emergency response in the event of an accidental release at the refinery.

The facility has submitted to the EPA a worst case and alternative release scenario for each regulated toxic substance held in the covered process, and a worst case and alternative release scenario for flammable substances in covered process units.

The EPA has provided the levels of concern (LOC) for certain regulated substances that have the potential to be carried offsite during a release. For regulated substances where emergency response planning guidelines (ERPG)

FACILITY DESCRIPTION
The Phillips 66 Ferndale Refinery is located in Ferndale, Washington, in Whatcom County. It receives crude oil from multiple sources, which it processes into petroleum products, including gasoline, transportation fuels, LPG, and oils. In addition to the flammable materials associated with crude oil processing, the facility uses hydrofluoric acid in the Alkylation Unit, which is a standard refining application. The processing of the crude oil results in the generation of hydrogen sulfide. Sulfur Recovery Units process the hydrogen sulfide and sulfur dioxide to recover sulfur for sale and to limit SO2 and CO2 emissions to atmosphere at quantities below the allowable limits. 

EXECUTIVE SUMMARY
The federal Risk Management Program requires the Phillips 66 Ferndale Refinery to submit a Risk Management Plan (RMP) for any processes containing regulated substances above their threshold quantities (TQ) at the Ferndale Refinery. The Ferndale Refinery handles hazardous materials onsite, and recognizes a responsibility to safely operate the facility in order to protect its employees and contractors, the surrounding community, and the environment. The facility has taken a proactive stance to promote the overall safe operation of the processes, with programs to prevent accidents from occurring, to plan for emergencies, and to maintain the equipment needed if an emergency does occur. The RMP summarizes existing programs and procedures so that these programs may be reviewed more efficiently.
The Ferndale Refinery processes oil into gasoline and refining products. The facility receives oil from many sources via ship, pipeline, and rail, stores it in tanks onsite, and then processes the oil into products to be shipped elsewhere by pipeline, railcar, barge, or truck. The refining process separates the crude oil into five products: gasoline, diesel fuel, liquefied petroleum gas (LPG), heavy fuel oil, and sulfur. All products are stored onsite prior to shipment.
